segment.source: User Account Control (Windows 10)
segment.target: User Account Control (Windows 10)

segment.source: User Account Control (UAC) helps prevent malware from damaging a PC and helps organizations deploy a better-managed desktop.
segment.target: User Account Control (UAC) helps prevent malware from damaging a PC and helps organizations deploy a better-managed desktop.

segment.source: User Account Control
segment.target: User Account Control

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: User Account Control (UAC) helps prevent malware from damaging a PC and helps organizations deploy a better-managed desktop.
segment.target: User Account Control (UAC) helps prevent malware from damaging a PC and helps organizations deploy a better-managed desktop.

segment.source: With UAC, apps and tasks always run in the security context of a non-administrator account, unless an administrator specifically authorizes administrator-level access to the system.
segment.target: With UAC, apps and tasks always run in the security context of a non-administrator account, unless an administrator specifically authorizes administrator-level access to the system.

segment.source: UAC can block the automatic installation of unauthorized apps and prevent inadvertent changes to system settings.
segment.target: UAC can block the automatic installation of unauthorized apps and prevent inadvertent changes to system settings.

segment.source: UAC allows all users to log on to their computers using a standard user account.
segment.target: UAC allows all users to log on to their computers using a standard user account.

segment.source: Processes launched using a standard user token may perform tasks using access rights granted to a standard user.
segment.target: Processes launched using a standard user token may perform tasks using access rights granted to a standard user.

segment.source: For instance, Windows Explorer automatically inherits standard user level permissions.
segment.target: For instance, Windows Explorer automatically inherits standard user level permissions.

segment.source: Additionally, any apps that are started using Windows Explorer (for example, by double-clicking a shortcut) also run with the standard set of user permissions.
segment.target: Additionally, any apps that are started using Windows Explorer (for example, by double-clicking a shortcut) also run with the standard set of user permissions.

segment.source: Many apps, including those that are included with the operating system itself, are designed to work properly in this way.
segment.target: Many apps, including those that are included with the operating system itself, are designed to work properly in this way.

segment.source: Other apps, especially those that were not specifically designed with security settings in mind, often require additional permissions to run successfully.
segment.target: Other apps, especially those that were not specifically designed with security settings in mind, often require additional permissions to run successfully.

segment.source: These types of apps are referred to as legacy apps.
segment.target: These types of apps are referred to as legacy apps.

segment.source: Additionally, actions such as installing new software and making configuration changes to the Windows Firewall, require more permissions than what is available to a standard user account.
segment.target: Additionally, actions such as installing new software and making configuration changes to the Windows Firewall, require more permissions than what is available to a standard user account.

segment.source: When an app needs to run with more than standard user rights, UAC can restore additional user groups to the token.
segment.target: When an app needs to run with more than standard user rights, UAC can restore additional user groups to the token.

segment.source: This enables the user to have explicit control of apps that are making system level changes to their computer or device.
segment.target: This enables the user to have explicit control of apps that are making system level changes to their computer or device.

segment.source: Practical applications
segment.target: Practical applications

segment.source: Admin Approval Mode in UAC helps prevent malware from silently installing without an administrator's knowledge.
segment.target: Admin Approval Mode in UAC helps prevent malware from silently installing without an administrator's knowledge.

segment.source: It also helps protect from inadvertent system-wide changes.
segment.target: It also helps protect from inadvertent system-wide changes.

segment.source: Lastly, it can be used to enforce a higher level of compliance where administrators must actively consent or provide credentials for each administrative process.
segment.target: Lastly, it can be used to enforce a higher level of compliance where administrators must actively consent or provide credentials for each administrative process.

segment.source: New and changed functionality
segment.target: New and changed functionality

segment.source: To find out what's new in UAC for Windows 10, see User Account Control.
segment.target: To find out what's new in UAC for Windows 10, see User Account Control.

segment.target: In this section

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: How User Account Control works
segment.target: How User Account Control works

segment.source: User Account Control (UAC) is a fundamental component of Microsoft's overall security vision.
segment.target: User Account Control (UAC) is a fundamental component of Microsoft's overall security vision.

segment.source: UAC helps mitigate the impact of malware.
segment.target: UAC helps mitigate the impact of malware.

segment.source: User Account Control security policy settings
segment.target: User Account Control security policy settings

segment.source: You can use security policies to configure how User Account Control works in your organization.
segment.target: You can use security policies to configure how User Account Control works in your organization.

segment.source: They can be configured locally by using the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc) or configured for the domain, OU, or specific groups by Group Policy.
segment.target: They can be configured locally by using the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc) or configured for the domain, OU, or specific groups by Group Policy.

segment.source: User Account Control Group Policy and registry key settings
segment.target: User Account Control Group Policy and registry key settings

segment.source: Here's a list of UAC Group Policy and registry key settings that your organization can use to manage UAC.
segment.target: Here's a list of UAC Group Policy and registry key settings that your organization can use to manage UAC.
